comments: This woman loves to assign tons of readings for regular class while having you read books outside of class and write responses for WHILE having you work on a semester long research paper, and throws in two massive take home tests forgoodmeasure. She also assumes all ic kids are rich and uses "white" and "privileged" synonymously.

Kim is really helpful and knowledable, assigned interesting reading and course material. Is a tough grader especially on written work, but the content you learn is worth it. I would definitely take a class with this professor again.

Prof Baker was VERY nice and I thought she was interesting. Her tests were kind of hard, but she tells you what to study. She paced the class well and had interesting in-class projects. Some of the assignments were cool, too. She\'s a harsh grader but I learned a lot and I really liked the class :-) I would recommend it

Prof. Baker is easily one of the best professors in the H&S school. She tells you exactly what to expect and challenges you to connect with the material. She is well organized and engaging. She is extremely helpful and understanding. Taking 3 courses with her has been invaluable to my degree.
She can teach statistics well. And the class fulfills the discipline\'s requirements as an intro soc course, but she is a bitter person who is often condescending.
good class, but she accused me of plagerism on a paper I was actually proud of, as a senior taking a last minute gen-ed... shes not cool at all, and treats her students like children...
Her class on drugs, was by far my favorite sociology class at IC

Baker was the worst teacher I had this last year. I can tell she was struggling to try and make the class interesting but for the most part she just put the lecture hall to sleep. Her grading is harsh - her instructions often contradict the rubric. I once got marked off for lack of citations in an assignment that supposedly did not require any.

It\'s an interesting course. I took this course fall 2008 and I learned more about the conceptualization of drugs in the U.S., policies that were created in the U.S. and internationally. I recommend the class.
